Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Examining the Development of Student Reasoning Skills Through Scaffolded Physics Instruction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a collaborative project involving North Dakota State University (Award DUE-1431857), the University of Maine (Award DUE-1431940), Penn State Greater Allegheny (Award DUE-1431541), the University of Washington (Award DUE-1432765), and Western Washington University (Award DUE-1432052).

In addition to helping students learn foundational physics content, one of the most important goals of a college-level physics course is to help students learn how to reason. To be successful in STEM fields, students must be able to build multi-step explanations leading to a prediction, an inference, or a conclusion. Experienced physics instructors recognize that this is difficult for many students. Although a great deal of research has been conducted on how students develop an understanding of individual concepts in physics, there has been little research to date on how students learn to chain ideas together. In many cases, instructional interventions have been shown to help the strongest students most, thereby widening the gap between high- and low-achieving students. Differences in students' underlying reasoning abilities might account for this disparity of impact. The outcomes of this project have the potential both to decrease such gaps and to increase the retention of at-risk students in STEM disciplines. Because this is a new avenue of research, one of the primary goals of this project is to develop tools and methods for the reliable measurement of student reasoning, and to test these tools with diverse student populations. These tools will be shared with other researchers so that they can be applied more widely in studies of the development of students' reasoning abilities in STEM courses.

Despite a sustained focus on reasoning and problem solving from a variety of research perspectives, little is known about how students construct inferential reasoning chains in solving qualitative physics problems. Because of the importance of reasoning in developing and applying scientific knowledge, as well as the relative lack of empirical and theoretical resources for understanding and assessing the development of such reasoning, there is a need for more research in this area. Central to this exploratory project is the development of new instruments and methodologies for disentangling conceptual understanding of physics from the reasoning abilities required to apply that understanding productively. Specific objectives of the project are (1) to develop instruments capable of reliably measuring student reasoning and (2) to use those instruments to investigate the development of student reasoning in university physics courses. The investigators will concurrently pursue both the development and refinement of instruments and the generation of new knowledge about students' reasoning in physics, including the identification of factors and instructional circumstances that enhance or suppress the application of productive reasoning approaches. The investigators will employ three complementary strategies: (1) the collection and analysis of snapshot data obtained from many students at a single instant (e.g., written responses to exam questions), (2) controlled experiments involving comparisons of snapshot data obtained under different circumstances, and (3) the collection and analysis of video data from student interviews and from groups of students working through materials in class.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project represents an important contribution to a larger effort to promote equity in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) education by fostering the development of scientific reasoning abilities for all students. One of the most important goals of a university-level physics course is to help students learn how to reason. Indeed, to be successful in STEM fields, students must be able to build multi-step explanations leading to a prediction, an inference, or a conclusion. Although a great deal of research has been conducted on conceptual understanding (i.e., how students develop understanding of individual ideas), there has been much less research on how students learn to chain ideas together in order to construct inferential reasoning chains (e.g., when solving qualitative physics problems). In some cases, instructional interventions have been shown to help the strongest students most, thereby widening the gap between high- and low-achieving students. This may be due to differences in students’ underlying reasoning skills, so efforts that support the development of students’ reasoning skills could help decrease such gaps and increase the retention of at-risk students in STEM disciplines.

 

Given the relative lack of resources for understanding and assessing students’ qualitative inferential reasoning skills, this project focused on the development of tools and methodologies for the reliable measurement of student reasoning. This involved disentangling conceptual understanding of physics from the reasoning skills required to apply that understanding productively. In particular, the project sought (1) to develop instruments capable of reliably measuring student reasoning, and (2) to use these instruments to investigate the development of student reasoning in university physics courses.  Much of this research was informed by dual-process theories of reasoning (DPToR). In DPToR, human cognition involves two interacting processes:  one is fast, automatic, and intuitive; whereas the other is slow, effortful, and analyticial.  

 

During this project, instruments and methodologies were developed, refined, and/or extended, and the resulting suite of instruments was employed to better understand the nature and development of student reasoning in physics. In particular, three instruments from this suite have been extensively refined and tested. Screening-target tasks consist of linked physics questions requiring application of the same knowledge and skills. The “screening” question requires students to apply their knowledge in a basic situation, while the “target” question features a related situation that calls for the application of the same knowledge, but that tends to elicit intuitive rather than formal responses. This methodology allows researchers to examine the reasoning of students who demonstrate that they possess the requisite knowledge but are unable to answer the “target” question correctly due to the nature of their reasoning approaches. In reasoning chain construction tasks, students are provided with correct reasoning elements (i.e., true statements about the physical situation as well as correct concepts and mathematical relationships) via an online interface and are asked to assemble them into an argument in order to answer a physics question, thereby focusing on the construction of the qualitative inferential reasoning chain itself. Finally, in follow reasoning tasks, students first answer a qualitative physics question (or base task) and are then asked to map fictitious students’ lines of reasoning on the base tasks to the corresponding answers, thereby indicating that they “follow” the line of reasoning.

 

These instruments (and others) have been used to (a) document the extent to which students can construct and/or follow chains of reasoning, (b) identify circumstances under which the ability to construct and/or follow chains of reasoning is enhanced or suppressed, and (c) document differences in reasoning skills in different instructional environments.  Screening-target tasks, reasoning chain construction tasks, and other methodologies have been used to explore the extent to which the nature of human reasoning, as modeled by DPToR, impacts student performance on physics questions.  In addition, performance data from screening-target tasks and network analysis of data from reasoning chain construction tasks have been used to examine the development of student reasoning during instruction.  In total, project instruments/methodologies and related research on student reasoning in physics have been disseminated widely via 8 peer-reviewed manuscripts (published or accepted), 5 manuscripts under review or in preparation, 33 invited talks, 40 contributed talks, 27 contributed posters, and 12 workshops.

 

Sample instruments have been posted on the website Techniques for Exploring and Assessing Physics Reasoning (https://sites.psu.edu/teapr/). Some of these instruments have also been adopted by education researchers in other disciplines.

 

Finally, efforts were also made to leverage the power of dual-process theories of reasoning to provide mechanistic accounts of observed reasoning patterns in order to develop modest instructional interventions intended to better support student reasoning in physics. These preliminary efforts led to a follow-up collaborative project entitled Establishing a new model for research-based curriculum development in physics aligned with dual-process theories of reasoning, which is aimed at strengthening the development of student reasoning skills in physics and in STEM more broadly.
